title: Secretary of State Rubio insists US and Europe 'belong together'
subhead: Marco Rubio's speech in Munich on Saturday marked a sharp contrast to that of US Vice President JD Vance a year ago, when he used the same stage to attack European policies on immigration and free speech, shocking European allies.

title: Marseille mayoral election: Who's running?
Trump threatens to bypass Congress and order new voting laws ahead of midterms
Ex-president Hollande's 2027 presidential election comeback is fraught with obstacles
subhead: Once dismissed as far-fetched just a few months ago, former Socialist president François Hollande's candidacy is now seen as a credible scenario. However, he must face several obstacles within both the broader left and his Socialist party.

title: How the Ivorian president's niece acted as Epstein's go-between
subhead: The Epstein files reveal the close relationship between the late financier and Nina Keita, who introduced him to young women and local business leaders. The niece of Côte d'Ivoire's president, Alassane Ouattara, now holds a senior position in Abidjan.

title: NBA star Chris Paul 'steps away' from basketball at age 40
subhead: Paul posted his retirement announcement on Instagram after being dropped following his trade to Toronto by the Los Angeles Clippers last week.

title: Saudi Arabia rethinks its cultural policy as foreign interests vie for funding
subhead: As the kingdom tightens its purse strings, French stakeholders have been working to protect their interests amid competition from the English-speaking world.

Ice hockey at the 2026 Olympics: A mountain sport looks to win over France's big cities
subhead: The majority of players on the French national team hail from urban centers. This shift reflects the changing landscape of the sport across the country.

title: Why are major powers competing for control of the Arctic?
subhead: The Arctic has become a strategic focal point for countries, lying at the intersection of climate and geopolitical challenges. Climate change has sharply accelerated this transformation.

title: 'The decline in birth rates is a social phenomenon, not a woman's responsibility'
subhead: Instead of questioning the collective factors behind declining birth rates, the dominant narrative shifts responsibility onto women, laments Brigitte Grésy, former president of France's High Council for Gender Equality, and Micheline Misrahi-Abadou, professor at the faculty of medicine of Paris-Saclay University.
